title: Spies Sent to Canaan
shortSummary: In Numbers 13, God commands Moses to send twelve leaders, one from each tribe, to spy out the land of Canaan, the Promised Land. The spies explore the land for forty days, bringing back fruit and a report that reveals both the land's richness and the formidable inhabitants, setting the stage for Israel’s response to God's promise.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Wanderings after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's command to send spies and oversees the mission.

keyCharacters.name: Caleb
keyCharacters.description: A spy from the tribe of Judah who encourages the people to trust God and possess the land.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua (formerly Oshea)
keyCharacters.description: A spy from the tribe of Ephraim, renamed by Moses, who stands with Caleb in faith and courage.

keyCharacters.name: The Other Ten Spies
keyCharacters.description: Leaders from the other tribes who give a fearful and discouraging report about the land and its inhabitants.

definitions.definition: The earliest and finest grapes of the season, symbolizing the fertility and abundance of the land.
A race of giants descended from Anak, known for their great size and strength, representing formidable opposition.
Cities fortified with walls for protection, indicating the strength and preparedness of the inhabitants.
A valley or stream area where the spies cut a large cluster of grapes, demonstrating the land’s fruitfulness.

outline.heading: God’s Command to Spy Out Canaan
outline.description: God instructs Moses to send one leader from each tribe to explore the land of Canaan, emphasizing the importance of leadership and obedience in God's plan.

outline.heading: The Twelve Spies Named and Sent
outline.description: Moses selects twelve men, each a tribal leader, including Caleb and Joshua, highlighting the unity and representation of all Israel.

outline.heading: Instructions and Exploration of the Land
outline.description: The spies are told to assess the land’s fertility, inhabitants, and fortifications, and to bring back fruit as evidence, demonstrating God’s provision and the reality of the challenge.

outline.heading: The Report of the Spies
outline.description: The spies return with a mixed report: the land is fruitful but inhabited by strong, giant people. Caleb and Joshua show faith, while the others spread fear, setting up a crisis of trust in God.

application: Trust in God’s promises even when circumstances appear daunting, as Caleb and Joshua did.
Obedience to God’s commands requires courage and faith, especially when facing opposition.
Evaluate situations with a God-centered perspective rather than a fear-driven one.
Encourage others to stand firm in faith and not be swayed by negative reports or discouragement.

keyVerses.text: And they told him, and said, We came unto the land whither thou sentest us, and surely it floweth with milk and honey; and this is the fruit of it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the truth of God’s promise about the land’s abundance and blessing.

keyVerses.text: And Caleb stilled the people before Moses, and said, Let us go up at once, and possess it; for we are well able to overcome it.
keyVerses.significance: Caleb’s confident declaration exemplifies faith and courage in God’s power to fulfill His promises.

keyVerses.text: And there we saw the giants, the sons of Anak, which come of the giants: and we were in our own sight as grasshoppers, and so we were in their sight.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the fear and unbelief that can distort reality and undermine trust in God.
